node.title: Yellen says it’s time to stop calling inflation ‘transitory’ as Omicron emerges.
node.alt: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen testified on Capitol Hill on Tuesday.
node.description: The Treasury Secretary said the new virus variant could further fuel price increases, but cautioned it was too soon know.
node.content: ["WASHINGTON \u2014 Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen on Thursday said she believed it was time to retire the term \u201ctransitory\u201d to characterize inflation as temporary and suggested that the Omicron variant of the coronavirus could prolong the problem of rising prices.", "Speaking at an event sponsored by Reuters, Ms. Yellen said that over the summer it appeared that the pandemic was subsiding and that the economy would soon normalize. The spread of new variants, she said, has changed that calculus.", "\u201cNow the new variant, the Omicron variant, the pandemic could be with us for quite some time and hopefully not completely stifling economic activity but affecting our behavior in ways that contribute to inflation,\u201d Ms. Yellen said.", "Ms. Yellen\u2019s remarks echoed those of Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, who said earlier this week that inflation was more than a short-term issue.", "\u201cI am ready to retire the word transitory,\u201d Ms. Yellen said. \u201cI can agree that that hasn\u2019t been an apt description of what we are dealing with.\u201d", "The Treasury secretary said that it was too soon to say what impact Omicron would have on the economy, noting that it could snarl supply chains and fuel further inflation, but that if it dampened economic growth it could blunt price increases. She warned, however, that it could cause \u201csignificant problems.\u201d", "\u201cWe\u2019re very uncertain at this point just how significant a threat it\u2019s going to be and closely watching the scientific evidence on this that\u2019s accumulating,\u201d Ms. Yellen said. \u201cHopefully it\u2019s not something that\u2019s going to slow economic growth significantly.\u201d", "She added: \u201cThis could again exacerbate supply chain and inflation problems.\u201d", "Ms. Yellen, a former Fed chair, said that the central bank was committed to using its tools to contain inflation but said there was little it could do to ease clogged supply chains. She said that Mr. Powell\u2019s suggestion this week that the Fed would consider speeding up its plan to withdraw financial support from the economy \u201cmakes sense.\u201d", "\u201cWhat we don\u2019t want to have develop is a wage-price spiral, in which inflation becomes its own self-reinforcing kind of phenomenon that would become chronic in the U.S. economy, something endemic,\u201d Ms. Yellen said."]
